heading: 2.1 absolute path
text: file path starts / appended working directoryFor example, working directory /Users//study/ want refer file directory data called faces.csv, absolute path /Users//study/data/faces.csv.However, normally use relative paths scripts, absolute paths, can change move project directory new computer even new place computer.package R.utils function getAbsolutePath() returns absolute path file path file object. caminho absoluto: um caminho para um arquivo que começa com / e não está fixado ao diretório de trabalhoPor exemplo, se o seu diretório de trabalho é /Users//study/ e você quer se referir um arquivo diretório data chamado faces.csv, o caminho absoluto é /Users//study/data/faces.csv.Entretanto, você deve normalmente usar caminhos relativos nos scripts, não caminhos absolutos, pois estes podem mudar quando você move o diretório de um projeto para um computador novo ou até mesmo para um destino novo seu computador.O pacote R.utils possui uma função getAbsolutePath() que retorna o caminho absoluto de um arquivo caminho ou um arquivoobjeto
code:
R.utils::getAbsolutePath("../index.Rmd")
#> [1] "/Users/debruine/rproj/psyteachr/index.Rmd"

heading: 2.3 alpha
text: (stats) cutoff value making decision reject null hypothesis; (graphics) value 0 1 used control levels transparency plotCan also parameter beta distribution refer Cronbach's alpha.(stats) alfa: o valor limite para tomar uma decisão ao rejeitar uma hipótese nula; graphics) um valor entre 0 e 1 usado para controlar os níveis de transparência em um gráficoPode ser também um parâmetro na distribuição beta beta distribution ou se referir ao alfa de Cronbach Cronbach's alpha.

heading: 2.4 alpha (stats)
text: cutoff value making decision reject null hypothesisIf using null hypothesis significance testing (NHST), need decide cutoff value called alpha making decision reject null hypothesis. call p-values alpha cutoff significant.psychology, alpha traditionally set \(\alpha\) = .05, good arguments setting different criterion circumstances.alfa: o valor limite para tomar uma decisão ao rejeitar uma hipótese nulaalfa (estatística): se você estiver usando o teste de significância da hipótese nula, você deve decidir um limiar de valor chamado alfa para tomar uma decisão sobre rejeitar hipótese nula. P-valores abaixo limiar alfa são chamados de significativos.Na psicologia, o alfa é tipicamente estabelecido como \(\alpha\) = .05, mas há bons argumentos para estabelecer um critério diferente em algumas circunstâncias.

heading: 2.5 alpha (graphics)
text:
value 0 1 used control levels transparency plotUm valor entre 0 e 1 usado para controlar os níveis de transparência em um gráfico
Figure 2.1: Setting alpha number lower 1 lets see parts plot hidden behind object.
code:
# if you omit alpha, it defaults to 1
alpha1.00 <- ggplot(diamonds, aes(x = depth, fill = cut)) +
  geom_density() + xlim(55, 70)

alpha0.25 <- ggplot(diamonds, aes(x = depth, fill = cut)) +
  geom_density(alpha = 0.25) + xlim(55, 70)

cowplot::plot_grid(alpha1.00, alpha0.25, nrow = 2,
                   labels = c("alpha = 1.0", "alpha = 0.25"))

heading: 2.7 ampersand
text: symbol &, operator meaning "".single ampersand vectorized, compares item first vector corresponding item second vector.double ampersand vectorised, ignore first item vectors, unless set environment variable _R_CHECK_LENGTH_1_LOGIC2_ true, case get error.advantage double ampersand stop soon conclusion obvious. first item FALSE, second item even run. useful testing whether object exists checking something requires object exist.
code:
c(T, T, F, F) & c(T, T, F, F)
#> [1]  TRUE  TRUE FALSE FALSE
Sys.setenv("_R_CHECK_LENGTH_1_LOGIC2_" = "false")
c(T, T, F, F) && c(T, T, F, F)
#> Error in c(T, T, F, F) && c(T, T, F, F): 'length = 4' in coercion to 'logical(1)'
Sys.setenv("_R_CHECK_LENGTH_1_LOGIC2_" = "true")
c(T, T, F, F) && c(T, T, F, F)
#> Error in c(T, T, F, F) && c(T, T, F, F): 'length = 4' in coercion to 'logical(1)'
# this produces an error if x doesn't exist
if (is.character(x)) { 
  # do something
}
#> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'x' not found
if (exists("x") && is.character(x)) { 
  # do something
}

heading: 2.8 ancova
text: ANalysis CO-VAriance: type linear model useful factorial designs continuous covariatesSee also ANOVA.
code:
# simulate some factorial data
set.seed(8675309)
simdat <- faux::sim_design(
  n = 100,
  between = list(treatment = c("control", "experimental")),
  mu = c(100, 105),
  sd = 10,
  id = "ID",
  dv = "DV",
  plot = FALSE
)

# add a covariate that is correlated r = 0.5 to the DV
simdat$cov <- faux::rnorm_pre(simdat$DV, mu = 0, sd = 1, r = 0.5)

head(simdat)
# analysis with ANCOVA

library(afex) # a useful package for ancova

ancova <- afex::aov_ez(
  id = "ID",
  dv = "DV",
  between = "treatment",
  covariate = "cov",
  factorize = FALSE, # must be FALSE with covariates
  data = simdat
)
#> Warning: Numerical variables NOT centered on 0 (matters if variable in interaction):
#>    cov
#> Contrasts set to contr.sum for the following variables: treatment

afex::nice(ancova)

heading: 2.9 ANOVA
text:
ANalysis VAriance: type linear model useful factorial designsSee also ANCOVA.
Figure 2.2: 2x2 factorial data
code:
# simulate some factorial data
set.seed(8675309)
simdat <- faux::sim_design(
  n = 100,
  within = list(time = c("pre", "post")),
  between = list(treatment = c("control", "experimental")),
  mu = c(100, 100, 100, 105),
  sd = 10,
  r = 0.5,
  id = "ID",
  dv = "DV",
  long = TRUE
)
# analysis with ANOVA

library(afex) # a useful package for anova

anova <- afex::aov_ez(
  id = "ID",
  dv = "DV",
  between = "treatment",
  within = "time",
  data = simdat
)
#> Contrasts set to contr.sum for the following variables: treatment

afex::nice(anova)

heading: 2.10 anti_join
text:
filtering join returns rows left table matching values right table, keeping just columns left table.

all_data <- tibble(
  id = 1:5,

to_exclude <- tibble(

data <- anti_join(all_data, to_exclude, by = "id")

heading: 2.12 array
text: container stores objects one dimensions.can create array specifying list vector values number dimensions. first two dimensions rows columns; dimension printed separately facet.can give array dimensions names.Objects need data type.
code:
# 3-dimensional array with 4 rows, 3 columns, and 2 facets
array(1:24, dim = c(4, 3, 2))
#> , , 1
#> 
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3]
#> [1,]    1    5    9
#> [2,]    2    6   10
#> [3,]    3    7   11
#> [4,]    4    8   12
#> 
#> , , 2
#> 
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3]
#> [1,]   13   17   21
#> [2,]   14   18   22
#> [3,]   15   19   23
#> [4,]   16   20   24

dimnames <- list(
  subj_id = c("S1", "S2", "S3", "S4"),
  face_id = c("F1", "F2", "F3"),
  condition = c("Control", "experimental")
)
  
array(1:24, dim = c(4, 3, 2), dimnames = dimnames)
#> , , condition = Control
#> 
#>        face_id
#> subj_id F1 F2 F3
#>      S1  1  5  9
#>      S2  2  6 10
#>      S3  3  7 11
#>      S4  4  8 12
#> 
#> , , condition = experimental
#> 
#>        face_id
#> subj_id F1 F2 F3
#>      S1 13 17 21
#>      S2 14 18 22
#>      S3 15 19 23
#>      S4 16 20 24
mylist <- list("A", TRUE, 2L, 3.1)
myarray <- array(mylist, dim = c(2,2))

c(
  myarray[[1,1]] %>% class(),
  myarray[[1,2]] %>% class(),
  myarray[[2,1]] %>% class(),
  myarray[[2,2]] %>% class()
)
#> [1] "character" "integer"   "logical"   "numeric"

heading: 2.15 atomic
text: containing objects data type (e.g., numeric character).Vectors atomic data structures R.try mix data types atomic vector, coerced type. (Note 32 becomes "32" can vector character object).Another feature vectors makes atomic always flat. embed vectors within vectors, flattened.Lists, hand, can nested.try extract objects inside atomic vector, need use brackets []. can index name. Single brackets can return one elements, include names, double brackets can return one element names.use $ operator atomic vector, get common error.See Vectors chapter Advanced R advanced discussion atomic vectors.
code:
a <- c(1, 4, 32)
b <- c("somebody", "once", "told me")
class(a)
#> [1] "numeric"
class(b)
#> [1] "character"
c(32, TRUE, "eighteen")
#> [1] "32"       "TRUE"     "eighteen"
c(7, c(1, 4, 32), 2, 6)
#> [1]  7  1  4 32  2  6
list(7, c(1, 4, 32), 2, 6) %>% str()
#> List of 4
#>  $ : num 7
#>  $ : num [1:3] 1 4 32
#>  $ : num 2
#>  $ : num 6
my_vec <- c(x = 3, y = 1, z = 4)
my_vec[2]
#> y 
#> 1
my_vec["y"]
#> y 
#> 1
my_vec[["y"]]
#> [1] 1
my_vec$y
#> Error in my_vec$y: $ operator is invalid for atomic vectors

heading: 2.16 attribute
text: Extra information R objectYou can access object's attributes attr(). example, datasets simulated faux attribute called "design" details design.
code:
data <- faux::sim_design(
  between = list(pet = c(cat = "Cat Owners", 
                         dog = "Dog Owners")),
  within = list(time = c(am = "Morning", 
                         pm = "Night")),
  mu = 1:4,
  r = list(cat = 0.3, dog = 0.6),
  dv = c(score = "Happiness Scale Score"),
  plot = FALSE)

design <- attr(data, "design")

design$dv
#> $score
#> [1] "Happiness Scale Score"

  x = LETTERS[1:3]

b <- tibble(
  y = c(T, T, F)
)

data <- dplyr::bind_cols(a, b)
a <- tibble(
  id = 1:3,
  x = LETTERS[1:3]

  x = c(T, T, F)

heading: 3.6 bind_rows

heading: 3.11 boolean expression
text: expression evaluates TRUE FALSE.Boolean expressions usually use relational operator, == > compare two values.
code:
# ==    Equal to    
1 == 1
#> [1] TRUE
1 == 2
#> [1] FALSE
# !=    Not equal to    
1 != 2
#> [1] TRUE
1 != 1
#> [1] FALSE
# >     Greater than
2 > 1
#> [1] TRUE
1 > 2
#> [1] FALSE
# >=    Greater than or equal to
2 >= 1
#> [1] TRUE
1 >= 2
#> [1] FALSE
# <     Less than
1 < 2
#> [1] TRUE
2 < 1
#> [1] FALSE
# <=    Less than or equal to
1 <= 2
#> [1] TRUE
2 <= 1
#> [1] FALSE
# %in%  Match operator  
"A" %in% LETTERS
#> [1] TRUE
"1" %in% LETTERS
#> [1] FALSE

heading: 3.14 brackets
text: Square brackets used subset container like vector, list, data frame, matrix (e.g., mtcars[[1]] mtcars[1:2]).use single brackets subset container, get back container items selected. contrasts double brackets, return single item container.can use single brackets select one items vector.use double brackets, can select single item vector. try select one, get following error messge.can select items index name. mylist[c("", "c")] returns list containing first third items.Single brackets return type container object subset, mylist[1] returns list containing just first item.Double brackets return type object single item selected, mylist[[1]] returns vector first item mylist.Single brackets let select rows columns data frame tibble, separate comma.omit rows columns, select .select one column data frame single brackets, get vector back instead data frame. can change behaviour using drop = FALSE.Tibbles always returns tibble.Double brackets can used single index name select column vector.row column values select single cell.use double brackets select single row data table.complex containers like 3-dimensional arrays can 2 values brackets, work principles.
code:
secret_code <- c(16, 19, 25, 20, 5, 1, 3, 8, 18)

LETTERS[secret_code]
#> [1] "P" "S" "Y" "T" "E" "A" "C" "H" "R"
LETTERS[[secret_code]]
#> Error in LETTERS[[secret_code]]: attempt to select more than one element in vectorIndex
mylist <- list(
  a = 10,
  b = 20,
  c = 30
)

mylist[c("a", "c")]
#> $a
#> [1] 10
#> 
#> $c
#> [1] 30
mylist[1]
#> $a
#> [1] 10
mylist[[1]]
#> [1] 10
data <- data.frame(
  id = 1:3,
  letter = c("a", "b", "c"),
  vowel = c(TRUE, FALSE, FALSE)
)

# rows 1:2 and columns 3:4
data[1:2, 2:3]
data[1, ] # row 1, all columns
data[, 1:2] # all rows, columns 1:2
data[, 1] # returns a vector
#> [1] 1 2 3
data[, 1, drop = FALSE] # returns a data frame
as_tibble(data)[, 1] # returns a tibble
data[["vowel"]]
#> [1]  TRUE FALSE FALSE
data[[1, "vowel"]]
#> [1] TRUE
data[[1, ]]
#> Error in `[[.data.frame`(data, 1, ): argument "..2" is missing, with no default
myarray <- array(1:8, dim = c(2, 2, 2))
myarray[2, 2, 2]
#> [1] 8

heading: 4.7 class
text: way categorise objectsA class similar data type, object can one class.Classes often control object printed. example, result t.test() list class "htest", printing result gives formatted output.unclass() object, longer gets specical printing styles.
code:
# character class and type
class("A")
#> [1] "character"
typeof("A")
#> [1] "character"
# numeric class and double type
class(1.1)
#> [1] "numeric"
typeof(1.1)
#> [1] "double"
# numeric class and integer type
class(1L)
#> [1] "integer"
typeof(1L)
#> [1] "integer"
# function class and closure type
class(mean)
#> [1] "standardGeneric"
#> attr(,"package")
#> [1] "methods"
typeof(mean)
#> [1] "closure"
t <- t.test(rnorm(10), rnorm(10))
typeof(t)
#> [1] "list"
class(t)
#> [1] "htest"
t
#> 
#>  Welch Two Sample t-test
#> 
#> data:  rnorm(10) and rnorm(10)
#> t = -0.87885, df = 16.532, p-value = 0.3921
#> alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0
#> 95 percent confidence interval:
#>  -1.5093996  0.6230434
#> sample estimates:
#>   mean of x   mean of y 
#> -0.07360206  0.36957606
unclass(t)
#> $statistic
#>         t 
#> -0.878845 
#> 
#> $parameter
#>       df 
#> 16.53224 
#> 
#> $p.value
#> [1] 0.3920801
#> 
#> $conf.int
#> [1] -1.5093996  0.6230434
#> attr(,"conf.level")
#> [1] 0.95
#> 
#> $estimate
#>   mean of x   mean of y 
#> -0.07360206  0.36957606 
#> 
#> $null.value
#> difference in means 
#>                   0 
#> 
#> $stderr
#> [1] 0.5042733
#> 
#> $alternative
#> [1] "two.sided"
#> 
#> $method
#> [1] "Welch Two Sample t-test"
#> 
#> $data.name
#> [1] "rnorm(10) and rnorm(10)"

heading: 4.9 coercion
text: Changing data type values vector single compatible type.try combine values different data types vector matrix, get coerced common type. Strings dominant means, try combine string another data type, data type coerced string. Doubles dominant integers numeric values dominant logical values.
code:
c(2L, T, F)  # integers and logicals become integers
#> [1] 2 1 0
c(1.5, T, F) # doubles and logicals become doubles
#> [1] 1.5 1.0 0.0
c(1.5, 2L)   # doubles and integers become doubles
#> [1] 1.5 2.0
c("A", 1.5, 1L, T)  # strings and anything become strings

heading: 4.22 covariance matrix
text: Parameters showing set vectors vary covary.covariance matrix related correlation matrix, also incorporates information standard deviations variables.matrix products standard deviations called "sigma". multiply correlation matrix, get covariance matrix.
code:
data <- faux::rnorm_multi(
  n = 100,
  mu = 0,
  sd = c(A = 1, B = 2, C = 3),
  r = 0.5,
  empirical = TRUE
)

cor(data) # correlation matrix
#>     A   B   C
#> A 1.0 0.5 0.5
#> B 0.5 1.0 0.5
#> C 0.5 0.5 1.0
cov(data) # covariance matrix
#>     A B   C
#> A 1.0 1 1.5
#> B 1.0 4 3.0
#> C 1.5 3 9.0
  # multiply SDs    A    B    C
sigma <- matrix(c(1*1, 1*2, 1*3,  # A
                  2*1, 2*2, 2*3,  # B
                  3*1, 3*2, 3*3), # C
                nrow = 3)
sigma * cor(data)
#>     A B   C
#> A 1.0 1 1.5
#> B 1.0 4 3.0
#> C 1.5 3 9.0

x <- c(1,2,3,NA)

#> [1] NA

#> [1] NA

#> [1] 2
x = rnorm()
#> Error in rnorm(): argument "n" is missing, with no default
x <- c(1,2,3,NA)
mean(x)
#> [1] NA
mean(x, na.rm = FALSE)
#> [1] NA
mean(x, na.rm = TRUE)
#> [1] 2
x = rnorm()
#> Error in rnorm(): argument "n" is missing, with no default

heading: 5.5 degrees of freedom
text:
number observations free vary produce known outcome.run 5 people ask age, know mean age 5 people 20.1, four people can age, 5th person must specific age maintain mean 20.1. mean age known outcome four people's age can vary freely, degrees freedom 4.need know degrees freedom (usually abbreviated df) interpret test statistics like t-values F-values.
Figure 5.1: p-values vary depending degrees freedom specific t-values t-test.
自由度 有n個觀察值且已知樣本平均值，不能用已知估計值推測的可變異觀察值個數。假設你想知道五位同班同學今年幾歲，而你事先知道五人平均20.1歲。樣本平均值是已知的估計值，你只能推測其中一位的真實年齡是20.1歲，但是其他四位回答的年齡可以是任何數值。這個例子的樣本有4個觀察值可自由變異，所以自由度是4。當你進行統計檢定如t檢定和F檢定，必須要知道正確的自由度(簡寫 df)。
Figure 5.2: p-values vary depending degrees freedom specific t-values t-test.
中文參考資料：林澤民(2017)。統計學中算變異量為什麼要除以n-1？什麼是「自由度」？

std_effect <- raw_effect / sd(dv)

code:
# simulate some factorial data
set.seed(8675309)
simdat <- faux::sim_design(
  between = list(
    treatment = c("ctl", "exp"),
    group = c("A", "B")
  ),
  mu = c(100, 100, 105, 110),
  sd = 10
)
# model using lm
model <- lm(y ~ treatment * group, data = simdat)
summary(model)
#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = y ~ treatment * group, data = simdat)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -28.086  -7.198  -0.092   6.872  35.072 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                     Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)           99.056      1.065  92.967  < 2e-16 ***
#> treatmentexp           5.357      1.507   3.555 0.000423 ***
#> groupB                 1.236      1.507   0.820 0.412703    
#> treatmentexp:groupB    4.827      2.131   2.265 0.024036 *  
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 10.65 on 396 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.1503, Adjusted R-squared:  0.1439 
#> F-statistic: 23.35 on 3 and 396 DF,  p-value: 6.17e-14
emmeans::emmeans(model, ~ treatment | group)
#> group = A:
#>  treatment emmean   SE  df lower.CL upper.CL
#>  ctl         99.1 1.07 396     97.0      101
#>  exp        104.4 1.07 396    102.3      107
#> 
#> group = B:
#>  treatment emmean   SE  df lower.CL upper.CL
#>  ctl        100.3 1.07 396     98.2      102
#>  exp        110.5 1.07 396    108.4      113
#> 
#> Confidence level used: 0.95
emmeans::emmeans(model, ~ treatment)
#> NOTE: Results may be misleading due to involvement in interactions
#>  treatment emmean    SE  df lower.CL upper.CL
#>  ctl         99.7 0.753 396     98.2      101
#>  exp        107.4 0.753 396    106.0      109
#> 
#> Results are averaged over the levels of: group 
#> Confidence level used: 0.95
emmeans::emmeans(model, ~ group)
#> NOTE: Results may be misleading due to involvement in interactions
#>  group emmean    SE  df lower.CL upper.CL
#>  A        102 0.753 396      100      103
#>  B        105 0.753 396      104      107
#>

heading: 10.9 intercept
text: Also referred y-intercept, constant corresponding value \(y\) variable (regression context, response variable) predictor variables set zero.value intercept predicted value model terms equal zero. Therefore, depends groups coded whether covariates centered.example, code shows data sampled two distributions means 100 105. Two different contrast coding schemes used code group variable: treatment sum.Treatment coding codes baseline group 0, intercept equal predicted mean value group.two groups, sum coding codes one group -1 +1, intercept equal mean predicted mean values group.
code:
set.seed(8675309) # for reproducibility

control <- rnorm(n = 50, mean = 100, sd = 10)
experimental <- rnorm(n = 50, mean = 105, sd = 10)

df <- tibble(
  dv = c(control, experimental),
  group = rep(c("control", "experimental"), each = 50),
  treatment = recode(group, control = 0, experimental = 1),
  sum = recode(group, control = -1, experimental = 1)
)
model_t <- lm(dv ~ treatment, data = df)

summary(model_t)$coefficients
#>               Estimate Std. Error   t value     Pr(>|t|)
#> (Intercept) 101.026918   1.318732 76.609163 2.930242e-89
#> treatment     3.992219   1.864968  2.140637 3.478461e-02
model_s <- lm(dv ~ sum, data = df)

summary(model_s)$coefficients
#>               Estimate Std. Error    t value      Pr(>|t|)
#> (Intercept) 103.023028   0.932484 110.482354 1.159104e-104
#> sum           1.996109   0.932484   2.140637  3.478461e-02

heading: 10.10 iteration
text: Repeating process functionRepeating process function useful want perform operation element list vector.example, may want check power two-sample t-test detect effect size 0.2 possible sample sizes 100 1000, incrementing 100. can "iterate" values n get power n.Many functions "vectorized" return vector results use vector argument. function takes care iteration .can also use apply() map() functions apply single function element vector list.
code:
n_range <- seq(100, 1000, 100)
power <- c() # make an empty vector

for (n in n_range) {
  pcalc <- power.t.test(n = n, delta = 0.2, sd = 1, 
                      type = "two.sample")
  power <- c(power, pcalc$power)
}

power
#>  [1] 0.2902664 0.5140434 0.6863712 0.8064964 0.8847884 0.9333687 0.9623901
#>  [8] 0.9792066 0.9887083 0.9939638
pcalc <- power.t.test(n = n_range, 
                      delta = 0.2, sd = 1, 
                      type = "two.sample")
power <-  pcalc$power
power
#>  [1] 0.2902664 0.5140434 0.6863712 0.8064964 0.8847884 0.9333687 0.9623901
#>  [8] 0.9792066 0.9887083 0.9939638
# apply power.t.test to each n and return a list of lists
pcalc <- map(.x = n_range, # vector to iterate over
             .f = power.t.test, # function to apply
             # other arguments to the function
             delta = 0.2, sd = 1, 
             type="two.sample")

# extract the "power" element from each element in pcalc
# and return a vector of doubles
power <- map_dbl(pcalc, getElement, "power")
power
#>  [1] 0.2902664 0.5140434 0.6863712 0.8064964 0.8847884 0.9333687 0.9623901
#>  [8] 0.9792066 0.9887083 0.9939638

heading: 17.1 p-value
text: probability seeing effect least extreme , real effect value testing (e.g., null effect)example, used binomial test test chance probability 1/2 (e.g., probability heads flipping fair coin), p-value 0.37 means expect see effects least extreme data (.e., 55 heads tails) 37% time just chance alone.P-values can one-tailed two-tailed. example two-tailed specify direction testing whether fewer heads expected chance fair coin. example one-tailed, indicates 18% chance getting 55 heads flipping fair coin 100 times.can see p-value half two-tailed value; true symmetric distributions like binomial distribution, distributions.one-tailed test using "less", p-value much higher, indicating 86% chance getting 55 fewer heads flipping fair coin 100 times.
code:
# test how likely 55 heads (or a more extreme value)
# is to result from 100 flips of a fair (prob = 0.5) coin
binom.test(55, 100, 0.5)
#> 
#>  Exact binomial test
#> 
#> data:  55 and 100
#> number of successes = 55, number of trials = 100, p-value =
#> 0.3682
#> alternative hypothesis: true probability of success is not equal to 0.5
#> 95 percent confidence interval:
#>  0.4472802 0.6496798
#> sample estimates:
#> probability of success 
#>                   0.55
# test how likely 55 (or more) heads
# is to result from 100 flips of a fair (prob = 0.5) coin
binom.test(55, 100, 0.5, alternative = "greater")
#> 
#>  Exact binomial test
#> 
#> data:  55 and 100
#> number of successes = 55, number of trials = 100, p-value =
#> 0.1841
#> alternative hypothesis: true probability of success is greater than 0.5
#> 95 percent confidence interval:
#>  0.4628896 1.0000000
#> sample estimates:
#> probability of success 
#>                   0.55
# test how likely 55 (or fewer) heads
# is to result from 100 flips of a fair (prob = 0.5) coin
binom.test(55, 100, 0.5, alternative = "less")
#> 
#>  Exact binomial test
#> 
#> data:  55 and 100
#> number of successes = 55, number of trials = 100, p-value =
#> 0.8644
#> alternative hypothesis: true probability of success is less than 0.5
#> 95 percent confidence interval:
#>  0.0000000 0.6348377
#> sample estimates:
#> probability of success 
#>                   0.55

# simulate some data
set.seed(8675309)

n <- 100

heading: 19.15 residual
text: Defined deviation observation model's expected value.Mathematically, residual defined observed value minus model's fitted value observation.example, linear model \(\hat{Y_i} = 3 + 2 X_i\) predicts value \(\hat{Y}_i = 7\) \(X_i = 2\). happen observed \(Y_i = 8\) observation \(\), residual observation \(Y_i - \hat{Y}_i = 8 - 7 = 1\).related slightly different notion error.example, simulate data two groups 50 means 100 105 (SDs 10).model intercept 101 effect group 4, meaning predicted value group 0 101 predicted value group 1 105. difference predictions observed values residual error.
code:
set.seed(8675309) # for reproducibility

group0 <- rnorm(n = 50, mean = 100, sd = 10)
group1 <- rnorm(n = 50, mean = 105, sd = 10)

df <- data.frame(
  dv = c(group0, group1),
  group = rep(0:1, each = 50)
)

model <- lm(dv ~ group, data = df)

summary(model)
#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = dv ~ group, data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -25.9878  -7.1828  -0.1015   5.8804  20.1878 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  101.027      1.319  76.609   <2e-16 ***
#> group          3.992      1.865   2.141   0.0348 *  
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 9.325 on 98 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.04467,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.03492 
#> F-statistic: 4.582 on 1 and 98 DF,  p-value: 0.03478

model$coefficients
#> (Intercept)       group 
#>  101.026918    3.992219
intercept <- model$coefficients[[1]]
effect <- model$coefficients[[2]]

df |>
  mutate(predicted = intercept + effect * group,
         residual = dv - predicted) |>
  group_by(group) |>
  slice(1:5) # show 5 from each group

heading: 21.7 tied ranks
text: two values/observations within variable identical assume rank order value.default rank() function (ties.method = "average"). can also set ties go order dataset (first), opposite order (last), random order (random), ties maximum value (max) minimum value (min).
code:
scores <- tibble(
  score = c(5, 5, 5, 15, 15)
) %>%
  mutate(
    rank = rank(score),
    first = rank(score, ties.method = "first"),
    last = rank(score, ties.method = "last"),
    random = rank(score, ties.method = "random"),
    max = rank(score, ties.method = "max"),
    min = rank(score, ties.method = "min")
  )

heading: 23.1 value
text: single number piece data.tidy dataset, cell contains one value.example, age column contains 3 values: mean, minimum maximum.

library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)

untidy <- data.frame(
  group = c("A", "B"),
  age = c("20.4 [18-25]", "19.9 [18-24]")

           sep = "( \\[|-|\\])",
           extra = "drop")

heading: 23.5 variance
text: descriptive statistic much average data point varies mean.Variance equal standard deviation squared.calculate variance summing squared differences data point mean (sum(diff^2)) dividing number data points minus 1 ((n-1))
code:
data <- c(1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9)
var(data)
#> [1] 7.5
sd(data)^2
#> [1] 7.5
m <- mean(data)   # calculate the mean
diff <- data - m  # difference between each data point and the mean
n <- length(data) # number of data points
sum(diff^2)/(n-1) # variance
#> [1] 7.5

# use the c() function to make a vector of strings or numbers
